post_text: It is with great sadness we report the passing of Murl Huffman on Friday, August 28. Mr. Huffman taught over 12,000 students during his career at West Carrollton. Many of his students joined him last year when he celebrated his 100th birthday. He began teaching in West Carrollton in 1945, but he never really retired. He continued to support the Pirates and would often comment on our Facebook posts, especially when we would post information about the golf team or his former students. His support of students will continue to be a legacy through the Murl Huffman Scholarship.

There are many unknowns as we prepare for the 2020-21 school year. We are still awaiting guidelines from the Governor and the Ohio Department of Education. When we receive them, we will be able to provide our families with more information. What we can tell our families as of today (June 26) is:

• Our plan is to have students back in school August 19.
• A remote learning option will be available for families who do not want their children to return to school in August.
• Our decision about reopening the school district will be dependent on the guidelines and requirements we receive from state and local health departments.

Additional information will be sent when we receive it including answers to questions regarding masks. It will also be posted on our website at westcarrolltonschools.com and sent to all of our Pirate families. We want all of our students to have a successful school year in both academics and health!

Ben Moran was the class of 2001 valedictorian, captain of the men’s cross country team, men’s track team athlete, and a member of the National Honor Society. After graduation, he went to the Air Force Academy and became a pilot of the AC-130H. He has been stationed in Arizona and California, and served as an Ambassador for the Airforce in Suriname. This month, he was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. His promotion came from being ranked number one by pilots, co-pilots and his flight crew. Ben is currently stationed in Mississippi where he lives with his wife and two children. He is pictured being congratulated by High School teacher, Beth Mitchell. post_text: It takes a long time to get a Valentine’s Day card from Alaska. One first grade student at Schnell just got her card yesterday. Not only was it from Alaska, it was also from the first person to complete the 2020 census! According to an article from the Anchorage Daily News, the census begins early in Alaska because the spring thaw will impede travel to and from remote villages. Lizzie Chimiugak is a 90 year old village elder from Toksook Bay. Lizzie speaks Yup’ik and got help from her daughter Katie Schwartz to send the card all the way to West Carrollton! It was part of a fun project for Mrs. Sanders’ class who colored states and countries on a map to show from where the cards came. One child received a card from Japan, and another child received a keychain from North Dakota. #wcpiratepride #haroldschnellelementary
